title: Resource Consumption DOS on Edgemax v1.10.6
vulnerability_information:
Resource consumption Denial of service.

1: The request below shows that when you feed the beaker.session.id cookie variable a payload of 250 characters or more, the web management portal will produce an error page showing full path disclosure and more as shown in screenshots error1.png and error2.png.  

GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.100
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:52.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/52.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Cookie: beaker.session.id=v8iG24fDKn8x5uD3V2uICZA1FJEoUJpqH5VTa03xB5blDRNOe5AfFp2GNIBpDX8th1IO8sS5ejsz4Swm175nUvipwU211S4n4RtCv0A6r18fsgJbrrbmhFT9k2cAXF3yyg0Uu0B0wPOWP7BOrMVnXp44aHoXSfJ06ZXk7HrD5J5R9AZIgQLmGutM9ESNxw3CVJtW4Rfxeh7JE2AD04B3g78FxRgBxY82I2Gzf6ZPMsc39d37LM90dd9cFA
Connection: close
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Cache-Control: max-age=0
-----------------------------------------------------------

2: When providing a valid length payload of 249 characters or less it will be stored as a *.cache filename in the /var/run/beaker/container_file/ directory,this can easily be turned in to a denial of service by filling up the space of the device with unique beaker.session.id requests.  The web portal will display either a 500 error as shown in DOS1.png or a python error screen as shown in DOS2.1.png and DOS2.2.png.  Typically the web portal will stop functioning after the /run mount has reached 50% by sending requests using iterations of 1-15681 as a beaker.session.id variable, however any length of payload can be used up to 249 characters.  This can be recovered from by deleting all files within the /var/run/beaker/container_file/ directory.


Although once the /run mount can not accept any more files /var/log will start to fill up with complaints about not being able to write to /var/run/beaker/container_file/, then after /var/log fills up the device will stop responding all together until it has been power cycled.  

3: I have created a video showing you how it is accomplished, I stopped the video at only 7% resources consumed on the /run mount as the video would be pretty long if we waited until the edgerouter went offline.  I am hoping this is enough for you to be able to reproduce this.  I am thinking that this could be fairly bad if made in to a python script along with google dorks and automation.  Or even a python script that someone has to only enter in an IP address and it will take the router offline in about 5 minutes or so until the router owner unplugs and plugs it back in.

## Impact

Any resources served by the edgemax device will be unavailable until the physical device has it's power cycled, then it should function as normal.  However it would be easy to just perform the attack again after it has been brought back online.
vulnerability_information_html:
Resource consumption Denial of service.

1: The request below shows that when you feed the beaker.session.id cookie variable a payload of 250 characters or more, the web management portal will produce an error page showing full path disclosure and more as shown in screenshots error1.png and error2.png.

GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.100
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:52.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/52.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,/;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Cookie: beaker.session.id=v8iG24fDKn8x5uD3V2uICZA1FJEoUJpqH5VTa03xB5blDRNOe5AfFp2GNIBpDX8th1IO8sS5ejsz4Swm175nUvipwU211S4n4RtCv0A6r18fsgJbrrbmhFT9k2cAXF3yyg0Uu0B0wPOWP7BOrMVnXp44aHoXSfJ06ZXk7HrD5J5R9AZIgQLmGutM9ESNxw3CVJtW4Rfxeh7JE2AD04B3g78FxRgBxY82I2Gzf6ZPMsc39d37LM90dd9cFA
Connection: close
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1

Cache-Control: max-age=0

2: When providing a valid length payload of 249 characters or less it will be stored as a *.cache filename in the /var/run/beaker/container_file/ directory,this can easily be turned in to a denial of service by filling up the space of the device with unique beaker.session.id requests. The web portal will display either a 500 error as shown in DOS1.png or a python error screen as shown in DOS2.1.png and DOS2.2.png. Typically the web portal will stop functioning after the /run mount has reached 50% by sending requests using iterations of 1-15681 as a beaker.session.id variable, however any length of payload can be used up to 249 characters. This can be recovered from by deleting all files within the /var/run/beaker/container_file/ directory.

Although once the /run mount can not accept any more files /var/log will start to fill up with complaints about not being able to write to /var/run/beaker/container_file/, then after /var/log fills up the device will stop responding all together until it has been power cycled.

3: I have created a video showing you how it is accomplished, I stopped the video at only 7% resources consumed on the /run mount as the video would be pretty long if we waited until the edgerouter went offline. I am hoping this is enough for you to be able to reproduce this. I am thinking that this could be fairly bad if made in to a python script along with google dorks and automation. Or even a python script that someone has to only enter in an IP address and it will take the router offline in about 5 minutes or so until the router owner unplugs and plugs it back in.

Impact

Any resources served by the edgemax device will be unavailable until the physical device has it's power cycled, then it should function as normal. However it would be easy to just perform the attack again after it has been brought back online.

activities.message:
Hi,

Thank you for your submission! Unfortunately, this particular issue you reported is explicitly out of scope as outlined in our security page:

>DOS attacks are not allowed

Your effort is nonetheless appreciated and we wish that you'll continue to research and submit any future security issues you find.

Regards.
@joystick
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

Thank you for your submission! Unfortunately, this particular issue you reported is explicitly out of scope as outlined in our security page:

DOS attacks are not allowed

Your effort is nonetheless appreciated and we wish that you'll continue to research and submit any future security issues you find.

Regards.
@joystick

activities.message:
Hi @grampae,

Sorry for the delay, the router didn't  went offline, only the web interface, the router still accessible over SSH.

Was you able to make the router go completely offline? Or at least reducing the performance of if primary functions such: routing, dhcp server, etc.

Thanks
activities.markdown_message:

Was you able to make the router go completely offline? Or at least reducing the performance of if primary functions such: routing, dhcp server, etc.

Thanks

activities.message:
Hi @ubnt-rubens 
Thanks for getting back on this, I'll be out of town until Sunday night.  When I get back I'll verify that everything besides the web interface is still available.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hi @ubnt-rubens , hope your weekend is going well.

A little bit about the setup I used in the attached video.  First I attached a synology diskstation to the edgerouter x, and made it get an ip address by dhcp through the edgerouter.  Then as shown in the video I showed an active web connection to the edgerouter and diskstation.  The video shows the /run mount already at 50% and the var/log mount being actively filled with error logs.  I also show an active ssh connection to the edgerouter.  As time goes on in the video the active ssh connection becomes more and more sluggish until it is non responsive.  I can also not create a new ssh connection to the device.

In the video you will see that the diskstation and edgerouter web access becomes non responsive, at this time I unplugged the diskstation, waited a minute, and plugged it back in to see if the dhcp server was still actively handing out ip addresses.  no such luck, as you will see by my nmap scan which only shows the 192.168.1.1 (edgerouter), before that nmap would see the diskstation every time.  

So according to the nmap scan, it still shows, dns, dhcp, http, https as open ports.  As far as them actually working and returning data to requests.  that appears to break with this DOS.  

Let me know if you require more information.

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @ubnt-rubens , hope your weekend is going well.

A little bit about the setup I used in the attached video. First I attached a synology diskstation to the edgerouter x, and made it get an ip address by dhcp through the edgerouter. Then as shown in the video I showed an active web connection to the edgerouter and diskstation. The video shows the /run mount already at 50% and the var/log mount being actively filled with error logs. I also show an active ssh connection to the edgerouter. As time goes on in the video the active ssh connection becomes more and more sluggish until it is non responsive. I can also not create a new ssh connection to the device.

In the video you will see that the diskstation and edgerouter web access becomes non responsive, at this time I unplugged the diskstation, waited a minute, and plugged it back in to see if the dhcp server was still actively handing out ip addresses. no such luck, as you will see by my nmap scan which only shows the 192.168.1.1 (edgerouter), before that nmap would see the diskstation every time.

So according to the nmap scan, it still shows, dns, dhcp, http, https as open ports. As far as them actually working and returning data to requests. that appears to break with this DOS.

Let me know if you require more information.

Thanks!

activities.message:
Thanks @grampae, I was able to reproduce, I believe it was my mistake, I probably didn't let the `/var/log` use to increase enough.

I'll consult with the DEVs about it, and give you a final response soon.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks @grampae, I was able to reproduce, I believe it was my mistake, I probably didn't let the /var/log use to increase enough.

I'll consult with the DEVs about it, and give you a final response soon.

activities.message: We're working on getting this fixed as soon as we can.
activities.markdown_message: We're working on getting this fixed as soon as we can.

activities.message: Thanks @ubnt-rubens  let me know if I can be of further help.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks @ubnt-rubens let me know if I can be of further help.

activities.message: @grampae Just something that I found: the router goes back to normal eventually, the stale sessions are deleted after a few minutes.
activities.markdown_message: @grampae Just something that I found: the router goes back to normal eventually, the stale sessions are deleted after a few minutes.

activities.message: That is good news!  I think when I was testing it I had let the intruder session run in the background so I didn't notice.
activities.markdown_message: That is good news! I think when I was testing it I had let the intruder session run in the background so I didn't notice.

activities.message: Thanks!  Is this going to be fixed in the next firmware update or is a patch being made?
activities.markdown_message: Thanks! Is this going to be fixed in the next firmware update or is a patch being made?

activities.message: Very likely will fixed in the next firmware release.
activities.markdown_message: Very likely will fixed in the next firmware release.

activities.message: Hey I had a question, I wanted to do a write-up on this find.  I realize that I cannot disclose anything related to ubiquiti which is fine.  Would you prefer I show you a copy of the write up prior to release or are you fine if I just redact anything and everything that could be linked back to ubiquiti?  Let me know and thanks again!

activities.message:
Hi @grampae, we will allow a partial-disclose in HackerOne one month after the problem is fixed, one month after that (two months after fixed) you can publish this finding.

Just let us review the content first.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @grampae, we will allow a partial-disclose in HackerOne one month after the problem is fixed, one month after that (two months after fixed) you can publish this finding.

activities.message: hello all, just curious if this has been addressed in a firmware update yet.  i didn't notice anything in the changelog for October's firmware update.  thanks!

activities.message: Hi @grampae, This was not fixed yet in ERX, although this was mitigated in other models.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @grampae, This was not fixed yet in ERX, although this was mitigated in other models.

activities.message: Thank you for the reply.  Do you know when this will be patched in the erx?
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for the reply. Do you know when this will be patched in the erx?

activities.message: Hi @grampae, the fix was not release in the version `2.0.0`, we are working to include the fix in future releases.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @grampae, the fix was not release in the version 2.0.0, we are working to include the fix in future releases.

activities.message:
Hi @ubnt-rubens I realize that 2.0.1 was recalled however I was looking at the release notes (https://community.ubnt.com/t5/EdgeMAX-Updates-Blog/EdgeMAX-EdgeRouter-software-release-v2-0-1/ba-p/2730978) and I was curious if the section mentioning
[Logging] - Set 2Mb systemd log file limit on ER-X/ER-X-SFP/EP-R6
was in reference to this vulnerability as after /var/run/beaker/container_file/ fills up /var/log starts to fill up.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Specifically this item in the changelog:
[WebGUI] - Fix bug that caused WebGUI/UNMS to become inactive if aggressive network scanners opens lots of unauthorized sessions
